Introduction

Scoliosis is an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, commonly associated with back pain, stiffness, and related somatic dysfunctions.  Osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) is beneficial in managing scoliosis by addressing musculoskeletal imbalances, reducing pain, and enhancing functional mobility.  This article discusses anatomic and biomechanical characteristics, monitoring and management strategies, and the role of OMT.

Incidence and etiology



Scoliosis affects approximately 2%-3% of the population, predominantly adolescents during periods of rapid skeletal growth.  Female patients are more commonly affected, particularly with spinal curves that progress and require intervention.  Most scoliosis cases (~80%) are idiopathic, meaning they have no identifiable cause.  However, scoliosis can also result from neuromuscular conditions (eg, cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy), congenital vertebral anomalies, trauma, and leg-length discrepancies.

Anatomy and biomechanics

Dextroscoliosis and levoscoliosis



Scoliosis involves lateral spinal curvature with vertebral rotation and associated sidebending, typically classified as either dextroscoliosis or levoscoliosis (

image 1
):



  • Dextroscoliosis is characterized by a spinal curvature convex to the right side, involving left sidebending of vertebral segments.
  • Levoscoliosis involves a curvature convex to the left, with right sidebending of spinal segments.

Functional versus structural scoliosis



Scoliosis curves can be either functional or structural:



  • Functional curves are temporary and typically result from muscular imbalances, postural habits, or leg-length discrepancies.  These curves resolve or significantly improve with positional changes or correction of underlying factors.
  • Structural curves are fixed deformities involving permanent vertebral rotation and sidebending, which persist regardless of position or posture.

Thoracic versus lumbar scoliosis



Curves are also categorized by spinal regions involved:



  • Thoracic scoliosis, involving the upper to midback, is commonly associated with rib prominence due to vertebral rotation.
  • Lumbar scoliosis, affecting the lower spine, frequently results in pelvic asymmetry and leg-length discrepancies.

Diagnosis and classification



Diagnosis involves clinical evaluation, palpation, and x-rays.  The standard method for quantifying spinal curvature is the Cobb angle, measured on an upright spinal radiograph (

figure 1
):



  • Identify the vertebrae at the superior and inferior ends of the spinal curve (most displaced vertebrae).
  • Draw parallel lines along the superior endplate of the upper vertebra and the inferior endplate of the lower vertebra.
  • The intersection of perpendicular lines drawn from these lines defines the Cobb angle.


Scoliosis severity classification is based on the Cobb angle, as follows:



  • Mild:  5-19 degrees.
  • Moderate:  20-49 degrees.
  • Severe:  â‰¥50 degrees.

Management

Principles of management



Management depends on scoliosis severity, rate of progression, and skeletal maturity (assessed via Tanner staging and radiographic markers):



  • Mild scoliosis:  Managed conservatively with strengthening exercises and OMT.  Follow-up imaging is usually unnecessary after reaching skeletal maturity due to low progression risk.
  • Moderate scoliosis:  Monitored every 6 months, primarily managed with spinal bracing (>18 hr daily) (
    figure 2
    ).  Rapid curve progression (>5 degrees per year) despite adequate bracing warrants surgical evaluation.
  • Severe scoliosis:  Typically managed surgically due to an increased risk of cardiopulmonary compromise (eg, restrictive lung disease, reduced preload impairing cardiac output) and further deformity progression.

Osteopathic manipulative treatment



OMT complements scoliosis management by addressing associated somatic dysfunctions, decreasing pain, and improving musculoskeletal function.  Common techniques include:



  • Muscle energy:  Facilitates improved vertebral alignment and reduces muscular tension.
  • Myofascial release:  Alleviates fascial restrictions and muscle imbalances.
  • Facilitated positional release:  Gently normalizes hypertonic muscles and vertebral dysfunction.


In addition, OMT addressing pelvic and lower extremity dysfunctions reduces compensatory mechanisms and enhances overall alignment and mobility.  Associated innominate asymmetry and leg-length discrepancies are discussed in a separate article.

Summary



Scoliosis is an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, often accompanied by vertebral rotation and sidebending, classified as either dextroscoliosis (convex curve to the right with left sidebending) or levoscoliosis (convex curve to the left with right sidebending).  Management involves understanding the incidence, etiologies, and differences between functional (temporary, reversible) and structural (fixed, permanent) curves.  Diagnosis and severity are assessed using the Cobb angle, which guides treatment and monitoring strategies.  Mild scoliosis is typically managed conservatively, moderate cases usually require regular monitoring and bracing, and severe cases may necessitate surgical intervention due to significant cardiopulmonary risks (
